titleStmt.title: An A,B,C. for children Here is an A,B,C, deuised with sillables, with the Pater noster, the Creed & the ten Commaundments in English. And by this booke, a man that hath good capacitie, and can no letter in the book, may learne to read in the space of sixe weekes, both Latin and English, if he giue theretoo good diligence, as it hath been diuers times prooued. Also you may learne thereby to write English truely and to knowe the true ortographie of the English tung..

And by this booke, a man that hath good capacitie, and can no letter in the book, may learne to read in the space of sixe weekes, both Latin and English, if he giue theretoo good diligence, as it hath been diuers times prooued. Title within ornamental border, initials throughout.
Reproduction of original in: Trinity College (Dublin, Ireland). Library.
Majority of text in English with "seauen peticions of the Pater noster" and "Articles of the faith" in Latin.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: An A, B, C. for children

argument.p: HEere is an A, B, C, deui≈øed with ≈øillables, with the Pater no≈øter, the Creed & the ten Commaundements in Engli≈øh.

¬∂ And by this Booke, a man that hath good capacitie, and can no letter in the Book, may learne to read in the ≈øpace of ≈øixe weekes, both Latin and Engli≈øh, if he giue theretoo good diligence, as it hath beene diuers times prooued. Al≈øo you may learne therby to write Engli≈øh truely and to knowe the true Ortographie of the Engli≈øhe tung.

div.p: ‚úö.A.b.c.d.e.f.g.h.i.k.l.m.n.o.p.q r.r.≈ø.s.t.v.u.w x.y. z. & . Íù∞. E≈øt. Amen.
A.B.C.D.E.F.G.H.I.K.L.M.N.O.P.Q.R, S.T. V.W.X.Y.Z.
¬∂ In the name of the Father, and of the Sonne, and of the holy Ghoa≈øt, Amen.

list.item: Na ne ne ni no nu
Cag ceg ceg cig cog cug

list.head: ¬∂ Con≈øonantes that goe before the vowels.
¬∂ Con≈øonantes that doo follow the vowels.
list.item: Ar ‚Ä¢ s er ‚Ä¢ s ir ‚Ä¢ s or ‚Ä¢ s vr ‚Ä¢ s

div.p: ¬∂ Heer follow ≈øeauen Vowels, which of nece≈ø≈øitie wee mu≈øt v≈øe needes in the Engli≈øh tung. a.e.i.o.u.oo.ee.
¬∂ Heere followe their dipthonges which of nece≈ø≈øitie wee mu≈øt needes v≈øe for the Engli≈øhe tung. ay.au.ee.ey.eu.ya.yo.oo.ou.

¬∂ Of the ≈øingle (e) and double (ee) and of the ≈øingle o and bouble oo. when the one and the other ought to be writ ten. The ≈øingle e, when he commeth alone in the latter end of a Sillable, or els with a Con≈øonant after him: ≈øhould be ≈øound ≈øhorte and out of the mouth, as when I ≈øaye thus. This bea≈øte I ≈øle, this Conny I fie, I break my hed, I goe to bed, I hurt my leg, this man doth beg All the≈øe woordes in the latter end of the≈øe rimes (that is) ≈øle, fle, hed, bed, leg, beg, are ≈øounded open without the mouth and ≈øomewhat ≈øhorte, therfore they would
be written with ≈øingle (e) & ≈øo the Italians v≈øe to ≈øound the ≈øingle (e) and ≈øo we ought to teach Children to ≈øound it in learning their Cro≈ørowe. But when I ≈øay thus, beholde I ≈øee, I kneele on my knee, this birde dooth breede, my no≈øe dooth bleed, this man I ween, is ≈øick in the ≈øpleen, all the≈øe woordes in the latter end of the≈øe rimes, (that is to ≈øaye) knee, breede, bleed, ween, ≈øpleen, are ≈øounded clo≈øe within the mouth, and ≈øome what more prolonged, therfo ‚Ä¢ e they would be written with the double (ee) for it is more conuement to prolong the double (ee) then the ≈øingle (e) and al≈øo more conuenient to make ≈øhort the ≈øingle (e) and not the double (ee) and the ≈øame rule would be ob≈øerued in the ≈øingle (o) and the double (oo) for when I ≈øaye thus. A barraine Do, is as ≈øwilt as a ‚Ä¢ o. I looue wel God, ≈ømite with ye rod. The≈øe woords do, to, god, red would be written wt ≈øingle (o) But when I ≈øay this woman I woo, this woorke I doo, the ble≈ø≈øed rood amend your mood, the≈øe woordes woo, doo, rood, mood, would be writteÃÑ with double (oo) and ≈øo ye double (oo) ought to be ≈øounded long, and within the mouth, & the ≈øingle (o) ≈øhort and out of the mouth, and we ought to teach our children to ≈øou ‚Ä¢ de the ≈øingle (o) in learning them the Cro≈øte we as the Italians ≈øound it. Neuertheles there is many woo, des in Engli≈øhe that men v≈øe to ≈øound ≈øomtime after the ≈øingle (e) and ≈øometime after the double (ee) and ≈øomtime after the ≈øingle (o) and ≈øomtime after the double (oo) yee may write them with ≈øingle (e) or double (ee) and with ≈øingle (o) or double(oo) at your plea≈øure.
When the ≈øingle (e) ≈øhould be written in the latter end of an Engli≈øhe woord to per≈øou ‚Ä¢ me the ≈øound, and when it ≈øhould not.

¬∂ There is other woords in our Engli≈øh tung written with ≈øingle (e) and ≈øounded open out of the mouth and prolonged, as when I ≈øaye thus. By coun≈øaile and ‚Ä¢ ede
I walked in a mede of ten Acres brede. The≈øe woordes rede, mede, brede, becau≈øe they are ≈øounded open out of the mouth they ought to be written with ≈øingle (e) and becau≈øe they are prolonged in ≈øonnd, they ought to haue an other ≈øingle (e) in the latter end of the ≈øillable to prolong the ≈øound, which wee v≈øe oftetimes in the Engli≈øh tung, throughout the fiue Vowelles. As when I ≈øaye thus. In the water I wade, I walke in the ≈øhade, my bowe is weake, I will it break, this pere is ripe, giue it a ≈øtripe, full weil I hope to drinke a ≈øope, my Pur≈ø≈øe of tuke, was made in luke. All the≈øe woords, wade, ≈øhade, weak, break, ripe, ≈øtripe, hope, ≈øope, tuke luke, are ≈øounded out of the mouth, and prolonged by putting to the ≈øingle (e) in the latter end of the ≈øillable. But if that (e) be put away: then ≈øhall the ≈øillables be ≈øounded ≈øhort as wad, ≈øhad, wek, brek, rip, ≈øtrip, hop, ≈øop, &c. Al≈øo in the≈øe pointes the Engli≈øhe tung is much more to be prai≈øed then the French, becau≈øe in French they write ofttimes many Lettrs that lee≈øe their proper ≈øound, but in Engli≈øhe we v≈øe to write no letter but they are ≈øounded, except it be in certaine woordes v≈øed of late, which are borowed of the French tung, which ≈øhall greatlye hurt the Engli≈øh tung if it be ≈øo continued. For in the Latin tung and other ≈øub≈øtantiall congrue languages, they v≈øe ≈øeldome ≈øuch errors.

¬∂ Al≈øo you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that mo≈øt commonly ≈øo oft as this letter (≈ø) commeth ≈øingle in the mid≈øt of any woord, or the latter end hauing this letter (e) immediatly following (≈ø) the (≈ø) ≈øhall beare the ≈øound of (z) as example, to mu≈øe much ma≈øeth the minde.

list.head: ¬∂ The Dipthonges for the Engli≈øhe tung. Ay, au, ee, ey, eu, ya, ye, yo, oo, oy, ou.
list.item: Aid maid raid fraid rain brain ≈øwain. Hail wail rail ait wait ≈øtrait hait haid. Rained wair aik.

Au Aud baud fraud gaun gaunt graunt awn haunt ≈øaunt fraunt.
This dipthong au is oft written in Engli≈øh with w.
Ee Flee gree fee heed meed greek week creep ≈øweep weep.
Ey Eyl eyld heyl reyk weyk teyk ≈øeyn heyn treyn heyr feyr.

Eu Eue lewd ≈øhrewd lewt rewin fewl new
This dipthong eu is written in Engli≈øh with w.
Oo Doo woo brood good ≈øtood wood hoof loof book ≈øhook took fool pool ≈øool tool toom boon moon ≈øoon.
Oy Roy ≈øoy lay ≈øoyl oyl foyl coyf ≈øoys noys.

Ou Lowd clowd town ≈øownd fower tower ≈øhower owl knowl bowl ≈øows mows rowt, dowt ≈øhowt tows frows:
¬∂ This dipthong ou, written in Engli≈øh with w.

div.head: The ≈øeauen peticions of the Pater no≈øter, in Latin and Engli≈øh.

p.hi: PAter no≈øter qui es in coelis: ≈øanctificetur nomen tuum, Adueniat regnum tuum. Fiat voluntas tua, ≈øicut in coelo & in terra. Panem no≈øtrum quotidianom da nobis hodie. Et dimitte nobis debita no≈øtra, ≈øicut & nos demitumus debitoribus no≈øtris. Et ne nos inducas in tentationem. Sed libera nos a malo. Amen.

div.p: OUr Father which art in Heauen halowed be thy name. Thy kingdome come. Thy will be doone in Earth as it is in Heauen. Giue vs this daye our daylye bread, and forgiue vs our tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, as we forgiue them that tre≈øpas again≈øt vs. And lead vs not into temptation. But deliuer vs from euill. So be it.

div.head: ¬∂ The Articles of the faith.

p.hi: CRedo in Deum patrem omnipotentem, creatorem coeli & terrae, Et in Ie≈øum Chri≈øtum filium eius vnicum dominum no≈øtrum. Qui conceptus e≈øt de ≈øpiritu ≈øancto. Natus ex Maria virgine. Pa≈ø≈øus ≈øub Poncio Pilato. Crucifixus mortuus & ≈øepultus. De≈øcendit ad inferna, tertia die re≈øurrexit a martuis. A≈øcendit ad coelos, ≈øedet ad dexteram dei patris omnipotentis. Inde venturus e≈øt iudicare viuos & mortuos. Credo in ≈øpiritum ≈øanctum, ≈øanc tam eccle≈øiam catholicam, ancto ‚Ä¢ uÃÑ communionem, remi≈ø≈øionem peccatorum, carnis re≈øurrectionem. Et vitam eternam. Amen.

div.p:
I Beleeue in God the father almighty, maker of heauen and Earth. And in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt his onely Sonne our Lord. Which was conceiued by the holy Ghoa≈øt, borne of the Virgin Mary, ≈øuffered vnder Ponce Pilate, was
crucified, dead and buried, he de≈øcended into hell. The third day he ro≈øe againe from the dead. He a≈øcended into Heauen, and ≈øitteth on the right hand of God the Father almighty. From thence he ≈øhall come to iudge the quick and the dead. I beleeue in the holy Gho≈øt, the holy catholick Church. The communion of ≈øaints. The forgiuenes of ≈øinnes. The re≈øurrection of the body. And the life euerla≈øting Amen.

div.head: ¬∂ The ten commaundementes of almighty God.
div.p: I Am the Lord thy God which haue brought thee out of the land of Egipt, out of the hou≈øe of bondage.
1 Thou ≈øhalt haue none other Gods but me.

2 Thou ≈øhalt not make to thy ≈øelfe any grauen Image, nor the likenes of any thing that is in Heauen abooue or in the earth beneath, or in the water vnder the earth, Thou ≈øhalt not bow downe to them nor woor≈øhip them, for I the Lord thy God am a geloÍù∞ God, and vi≈øite the ≈øinnes of the Fathers vpon the Children, vnto the third and fourth generation, of them that hate me and ≈øhewe mercy vnto thou≈øandes, in them that looue me and keepe my commaundementes.
3 Thou ≈øhalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vaine, for the Lord will not holde him giltles that taketh his name in vaine.

4 Remember that thou keepe holy the Sabboth day, ≈øix dayes ≈øhalt thou labour and doo all that thou ha≈øt to doo: but the ≈øeauenth daye is the Sabboth of the Lord thy God. In it thou ≈øhalt doo no manner of woorke, thou and thy Sonne and thy Daughter, thy Man ≈øeruant, and thy Maide Seruant, thy Cattell and the Straunger that is within thy Gates, for in ≈øixe dayes the LORD
made heauen and earth, the Sea and all that in them is, and re≈øted the ≈øeauenth day. Wherefore the Lord ble≈ø≈øed the ≈øeauenth day and hallowed it.
5 Honor thy Father and Mother that thy deies may be long in the Land which the Lord thy God giueth thee.
6 Thou ≈øhalt doo no murder. 7. Thou ≈øhalt not commit adultrie. 8. Thou ≈øhalt not ≈øteale. 9 Thou ≈øhalt not beare falce witnes again≈øt thy neighbour.
10. Thou ≈øhalt not couet thy Neighbours hou≈øe, thou ≈øhalt not couet thy neighbours Wife, nor his ≈øeruant nor his Maide, nor his Oxe, nor his A≈ø≈øe, nor any thing that is his.

div.head: ¬∂ A praier before meat.
div.p: O Merciful Father, the which nouri≈øhe≈øt al creatures, feede vs with thy giftes, that we mi≈øu≈øe them not, but being ≈øtrengthened thereby to all hone≈øt labour and good woorkes, may liue vertuou≈øly & godlily in thy light, th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ owe Chri≈øt our Lord. Amen.

div.head: ¬∂ A Prayer after meat.
div.p: WE thanke thee Lord God heauenlye Father, for thy manyfolde benefites, and we be≈øeeche thee further, that as thou ha≈øt fed our bodies with corporall meate, ≈øo thou wilt al≈øo fatherlye maintaine our ≈øoules alwaye in true faith and knowledge of thee, through thy deerlye beloued ≈øonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.

list.head: Heer after follow Precepts of good liuing.
list.item: Doo to thy Neighbour as thou would≈øt be doon vnto.
Be not enuious at the pro≈øperitie of thy Neighbour.
Thou ≈øhalt beare no fal≈øe witnes again≈øt thy neighbour.
Bridle the affections of thy minde.
Beleeue and tru≈øt in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu.
Call oft for grace of the holy Ghoa≈øt.
Tru≈øt in the mercy of God.
Be true in woord and deed.
Be benigne and louing to thine inferiours.
Euer take a fre≈øh new good purpo≈øe.
Teach that thou ha≈øt learned louingly,
By this way thou ≈øhalt coÃÑe to grace and glory.

div.p: Imprinted at London for Abraham Veale, dwelling in Paules Churchyard at the ≈øigne of the Lamb.
